text: Many indicators for Part B are prepopulated, and at times, a template for writing is provided.   We also receive measurement tables and instructions.  All of these are received too late each year. We begin writing in the spring when data begins to trickle in.  We often do not receive templates till October, and all other supporting documents seem to come in December.  Prepopulation of data is usually around winter break, which causes a delay in writing.  I propose that the new APR year in grads be available after the clarification week in the spring.  Alternatively, it should be ready by September, and all instructions, measurement tables, prepopulation should occur at that time.
label: veryneg

text:
When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Exploring Industry Practices on Distribution and Display of Airline Fare, Schedule, and Availability Information

text: I support the recommended Mallows Bay-Potomac River National Marine Sanctuary.
label: pos
docAbstract: NOAA proposes to designate approximately 52 square miles of waters encompassing and surrounding Maryland’s Mallows Bay as the Mallows Bay – Potomac River National Marine Sanctuary (MPNMS or sanctuary). NOAA also proposes regulations to implement the sanctuary designation and establish the sanctuary’s terms of designation to protect historical, archeological, and cultural resources of national significance. A draft environmental impact statement (DEIS) and draft management plan have also been prepared for this proposed action.

text:
any thing that is a known health risk and causes death should be banned

I am writing in strong support of Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) proposed rule titled, "General and Plastic Surgery Devices: Restricted Sale, Distribution, and Use of Sunlamp Products."

I commend the FDA on its leadership in regulating sunlamps and for taking this important step to protect the public health. It is estimated that indoor tanning causes upwards of 400,000 cases of skin cancer in the U.S. each year. In fact, using indoor tanning beds before age 35 can increase your risk of melanoma - the deadliest form of skin cancer - by 59% and the risk increases with each use.

I also support the FDA's proposed risk acknowledgement form that adults would have to sign before using tanning beds and booths. Quite a bit of misinformation exists on indoor tanning and some people think they are safe and beneficial. The FDA's efforts will help correct this misinformation and educate adults about the risks associated with indoor tanning.

Restricting teens' access to indoor tanning and educating all users about the dangers of tanning devices are critical steps to preventing skin cancer. Together with the FDA's final rule reclassifying sunlamp products and the proposed rule updating sunlamp performance standards, this proposed rule will make a significant impact in reducing the incidence of skin cancer in the U.S. I urge the FDA to finalize this proposed rule.
label: verypos
docAbstract: Open

text:
To whom it may concern,
I am voicing my opinion in that I do NOT support the FDA changing the nutritional label for honey to include "added sugars". Changing the labels to include "added sugars" will confuse the consumers. The added sugars makes it seem as if the Beekeeper are adding additional sugar or adulterating the honey. I see no benefit in changing the labels, all it will do is confuse the consumer and possibly hurt domestic honey sales. Please do NOT change the nutritional label for honey.

Thank you,
Nick Thill
Wisconsin beekeeper

text:
I am a small organic farmer and I oppose the organic checkoff.
I already have a large amount of paperwork and an inspection to contend with.
label: veryneg

text:
It is important for families like mine to be able to choose organic. That is why I am writing to let you know I support the creation of an organic check-off. I try to buy the most organic products I can for my family, because I know that when I do, Im supporting an agricultural system that is good for our planet.

I believe that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order (AMS-SC-16-0112) is a terrific advancement that will lead to more organic food and farming.

Organic demand is growing so fast because more and more families like mine recognize the benefits of organic. Organic provides a choice not only for consumers, but also for farmers and businesses. Young people who want to get into farming in a smaller, sustainable way can choose the organic path. Small businesses can get into the organic market and make a go of it. Organic is providing more choices and more opportunities for everyone.

The organic check-off model offers the smallest farmers and businesses the option to choose whether or not to participate. This program has been designed fairly to not overburden the smaller operators, while also providing valuable benefits to these smaller-scale enterprises. It would raise funds to finance more research and assistance for farmers wanting to go organic. It would promote the benefits of organic through public education programs, which would help small businesses promote their organic brands. And, it wont cost taxpayers anything.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.
label: verypos

text: I am an organic farmer and have raised our family of six on it for 27 years and counting. The organic movement does not need any tax collected for a check-off scheme. Having a tax means less income for us small farmers trying to raise families and more money going to the big growers. The USDA needs to stay out of it. Please do not do any such thing.
label: veryneg

text:
The organic business does not need a check off program. The dairy program has had a check off for years. It did nothing to help stabilize the milk price and look at all the dairy farmers that have gone out of business. The pork program had a check off and look how many hog farmers have gone out of business.

Up until recently, the organic dairy could not supply all the demand so we don't need the government getting involved and trying to build up a business that we already can't meet.

Our family has been in the dairy business since 1847 and would like to continue this history with our children. Every time the government gets involved, they only seems to look at the big business and not the small individual family farm. Let us run our own busines.
label: veryneg

text:
Thank you for this opportunity to provide comment on the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Services (AMSs) proposed rule on an Organic Research, Promotion, and Information order (docket AMS-SC-16-0112).



Organic food, textiles and farming are important to me and my family, so I support the creation of an organic check-off. Families, like mine, across the country, value the opportunity to choose organic.



Its simple- we need more organic, not less. We need more organic farmers in the U.S. We need more public education about the benefits of organic. We need to make organic options more affordable and more attainable for everyone. Organic is the fastest growing segment of the food industry, and while local farmers and some of my favorite big brands offer organic products, fewer than 1% of farms in the U.S. are organic.



I look forward to the Department considering comments from organic stakeholders. This program wont cost tax payers a dime and Congress paved the way for its creation with bipartisan support. I urge USDA to move forward toward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.



The organic check-off model allows for this valuable industry investment and creatively offers the smallest farmers the option to choose whether or not to participate. Im happy to see a fair program that wont overburden small farms.



As a consumer, I support credible public education so shoppers understand what the USDA Organic seal means and why they should trust it.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity to comment, and look forward to more organic!
label: verypos

text: See attached
label: neut
docAbstract: EPA is proposing to add natural gas processing (NGP) facilities (also known as natural gas liquid extraction facilities) to the scope of the industrial sectors covered by the reporting requirements of section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) commonly known as the Toxics Release Inventory (TRI) and section 6607 of the Pollution Prevention Act of 1990 (PPA), 42 U.S.C. section 13106. Adding these facilities would meaningfully increase the information available to the public on releases and other waste management of listed chemicals from the natural gas processing sector and further the purposes of section 313 of EPCRA. EPA estimates that at least 282 NGP facilities in the United States would meet the TRI employee threshold (10 full-time employees or equivalent) and manufacture, process, or otherwise use (threshold activities) at least one TRI-listed chemical in excess of applicable threshold quantities. NGP facilities in the U.S. manufacture, process, or otherwise use more than 21 different TRI-listed chemicals, including n-hexane, hydrogen sulfide, toluene, benzene, xylene, and methanol. EPA expects that TRI reporting by United States NGP facilities would provide significant release and waste management data on these chemicals to the public.

EPA estimates that at least 282 NGP facilities in the United States would meet the TRI employee threshold (10 full-time employees or equivalent) and manufacture, process, or otherwise use (threshold activities) at least one TRI-listed chemical in excess of applicable threshold quantities. NGP facilities in the U.S. manufacture, process, or otherwise use more than 21 different TRI-listed chemicals, including n-hexane, hydrogen sulfide, toluene, benzene, xylene, and methanol. EPA expects that TRI reporting by United States NGP facilities would provide significant release and waste management data on these chemicals to the public.

text:
NORTHWEST HORTICULTURAL COUNCIL
105 S. 18th Street, Suite 105
YAKIMA, WASHINGTON 98901 USA
(509) 453-3193 FAX (509) 457-7615
www.nwhort.org

March 6, 2017

Docket Clerk,
Marketing Order and Agreement Division
Specialty Crops Program
AMS/USDA
1400 Independence Avenue SW, Stop 0237
Washington, D.C.
20250-0237

RE: Docket Number: AMS-SC-16-0112; PR-A1
"Organic Research, Promotion, and Information Order" as published on page 5746 of the Federal Register of Wednesday, January 18, 2017.

We oppose the establishment of an "Organic Research, Promotion, and Information Order."

The Northwest Horticultural Council, based in Yakima, Washington, represents producers and marketers of apples, pears, and cherries, both conventional and organic, in the Pacific Northwest.
Oregon and Washington are two of the five states where organic production of these tree-fruits is primarily located. Apples are one of the most valuable of the commercially-grown organic crops in the United States.
The Northwest Horticultural Council rejects each of the three foundational justifications given by USDA in support of the creation of a new federal intrusion into the lives of our organic growers, packers, and marketers: Domestic supply shortages, need for viable pest management in organic, and market confusion.

1.Domestic supply shortages are best left to the private marketplace to sort out. If there is a sufficient price benefit given to producing organic produce, it will be grown. No federal marketing order will change this.
2.The prioritizing and funding of needed research is better left to those interested in individual commodities. Why should money taxed of an organic apple grower go to research for organic row crops? Federal, state, and private systems already exist to handle the research needs of U.S. agriculture. For example, USDA's Agricultural Research Service, the Land Grant University system, and, in the case of our industry, the Washington Tree Fruit Research Commission, which is funded by growers.
3.We do not see the need to create a federal mandatory taxing mechanism for the purpose of "educating consumers on the meaning of the USDA organic label."

We also think that placing the economic burden of this proposed order on successful commercial growers while exempting small organic producers is wrong. Additionally, we think the proposed governing structure is unwieldy and would be a lightning rod for future civil litigation.
With the current Administration's drive to reduce federal red tape, it is unthinkable that this proposal will go forward in the absent of any established clear need. We urge its rejection by the Department of Agriculture.

Sincerely,

NORTHWEST HORTICULTURAL COUNCIL

Christian Schlect
President
cc. NHC Science Advisory Committee - Organic Subcommittee

text:
It is my personal right, as an American, to make the decision if I want to tan indoors/outdoors, not the governments, or any other group of people.
People are instructed by doctors every day to visit the tanning bed for a number of ailments, including those under the age of 18, and I as a parent should be able to allow my child access to indoor tanning if I see fit.
I am a middle class hard working citizen that cannot afford a $150 dermatologist visit, for a skin condition. With indoor tanning, I am able to treat it at a much lower cost. The government should not dictate the form of treatment I choose.
It is unfair to regulate my rights based off of opinions of dermatologist. Please read all the science before making a decision.
Tanning is a natural and intended body function. Our bodies were designed to receive sunlight and creating a tan is part of that process.
Professional indoor tanning salons believe in teaching moderation and sunburn prevention.
Professional indoor tanning salon employees go through comprehensive evaluations with clients, including their sun sensitivity (skin type). Clients with sun-sensitive skin that cannot tan (Skin Type 1) are not permitted to use UV tanning services and are directed to use non-UV spray tanning.
Clients are taught sunburn prevention and the appropriate use of outdoor sunscreen. This education, combined with the fact that a tan is natures protection against sunburn, is why indoor tanning clients are up to 81 percent less likely to sunburn outdoors as compared to non-tanners, according to surveys.
I have had family members who have been instructed by their doctor to visit an indoor tanning facility because of their lack of Vitamin D. It has helped them dramatically

text:
It is important for families like mine to be able to choose organic. That is why I am writing to let you know I support the creation of an organic check-off. I try to buy the most organic products I can for my family, because I know that when I do, Im supporting an agricultural system that is good for our planet.

I believe that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order (AMS-SC-16-0112) is a terrific advancement that will lead to more organic food and farming.

Organic demand is growing so fast because more and more families like mine recognize the benefits of organic. Organic provides a choice not only for consumers, but also for farmers and businesses. Young people who want to get into farming in a smaller, sustainable way can choose the organic path. Small businesses can get into the organic market and make a go of it. Organic is providing more choices and more opportunities for everyone.

The organic check-off model offers the smallest farmers and businesses the option to choose whether or not to participate. This program has been designed fairly to not overburden the smaller operators, while also providing valuable benefits to these smaller-scale enterprises. It would raise funds to finance more research and assistance for farmers wanting to go organic. It would promote the benefits of organic through public education programs, which would help small businesses promote their organic brands. And, it wont cost taxpayers anything.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

text:
Dear FDA,
I support the concerns of the Pollinator Stewardship Council and the American Honey Producers Association over the FDA requirement of packaged honey to include a nutrition label listing both "Total Sugars" and "Added Sugars." This requirement does not distinguish between the two sugar types. Therefore, labels will need to include the same amount of grams of sugar under each category e.g. "17 grams of Total Sugar" and "17 grams of Added Sugars." This will confuse food consumers.

If this label is implemented at the commercial beekeeping level it will begin the misinformation to food consumers that sugar is added to honey. Eventually, it will create confusion across the honey industry and mislead the consumer about a natural product.
As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is."

If consumers are informed through the Nutrition Facts label that honey contains "Added Sugars" then consumers may be led to believe that honey is adulterated, by the regulatory definition, with sugars added to develop or enhance its sweetness.

I realize that honey is added to foods in preparation or manufacturing and in that case it is clearly an added sugar in those foods and would therefore be labeled as "Added Sugars" on the Nutrition Facts label. However, pure honey, itself, does not contain added sugars.

I share the desire for clear, understandable nutrition information to aid consumer choice.
My desire, as is the FDA's, is to inform consumer food choices to promote public health without confusion or misbranding around pure honey.

I encourage the FDA to consider listing the naturally occurring sugar content of 100% pure honey as a "Total Sugar" and not "Added Sugars."

I join with the Honey and Pollination Center, Robert Mondavi Institute, UC Davis, the Pollinator Stewardship Council, and the American Honey Producers Association, to express concern of the FDA requirement for packaged honey to include a nutrition label listing both "Total Sugars" and "Added Sugars."
This requirement does not distinguish between the two sugar types. Therefore, labels will need to include the same amount of grams of sugar under each category e.g. "17 grams of Total Sugar" and "17 grams of Added Sugars."
Not only is this confusing for consumers, it is also incorrect. There are no added sugars in pure honey. Honey is a totally natural product.
As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is."
If consumers are informed through the Nutrition Facts label that honey contains "Added Sugars" then consumers may be led to believe that honey is adulterated, by the regulatory definition, with sugars added to develop or enhance its sweetness.
David Asia

text:
Thank you for this opportunity to provide comment on the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order (docket #XXXX).



Organic food, textiles and farming are important to me and my family, so I support the creation of an organic check-off. Families, like mine, across the country, value the opportunity to choose organic.



Its simple- we need more organic, not less. We need more organic farmers in the U.S. We need more public education about the benefits of organic. We need to make organic options more affordable and more attainable for everyone. Organic is the fastest growing segment of the food industry, and while local farmers and some of my favorite big brands offer organic products, fewer than 1% of farms in the U.S. are organic.



I look forward to the Department considering comments from organic stakeholders. This program wont cost tax payers a dime and Congress paved the way for its creation with bipartisan support. I urge USDA to move forward toward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.



The organic check-off model allows for this valuable industry investment and creatively offers the smallest farmers the option to choose whether or not to participate. Im happy to see a fair program that wont overburden small farms.



As a consumer, I support credible public education so shoppers understand what the USDA Organic seal means and why they should trust it.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity to comment, and look forward to more organic!
label: verypos

text:
When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Exploring Industry Practices on Distribution and Display of Airline Fare, Schedule, and Availability Information

text:
It is important for families like mine to be able to choose organic. That is why I am writing to let you know I support the creation of an organic check-off. I try to buy the most organic products I can for my family, because I know that when I do, Im supporting an agricultural system that is good for our planet.

I believe that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order (AMS-SC-16-0112) is a terrific advancement that will lead to more organic food and farming.

Organic demand is growing so fast because more and more families like mine recognize the benefits of organic. Organic provides a choice not only for consumers, but also for farmers and businesses. Young people who want to get into farming in a smaller, sustainable way can choose the organic path. Small businesses can get into the organic market and make a go of it. Organic is providing more choices and more opportunities for everyone.

The organic check-off model offers the smallest farmers and businesses the option to choose whether or not to participate. This program has been designed fairly to not overburden the smaller operators, while also providing valuable benefits to these smaller-scale enterprises. It would raise funds to finance more research and assistance for farmers wanting to go organic. It would promote the benefits of organic through public education programs, which would help small businesses promote their organic brands. And, it wont cost taxpayers anything.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.
label: verypos

docAbstract:
The Department of Veterans
Affairs (VA) amends its regulation
regarding fertility counseling and
treatment available to certain veterans
and spouses. VA currently provides
certain infertility services other than in
vitro fertilization (IVF) to veterans as
part of the medical benefits package.
IVF is the process of fertilization by
manually fertilizing an egg, and then
transferring the embryo to the uterus.
This interim final rulemaking adds a
new section authorizing IVF for a
veteran with a service-connected
disability that results in the inability of
the veteran to procreate without the use
of fertility treatment. In addition, we
add a new section stating that VA may
provide fertility counseling and
treatment using assisted reproductive
technologies (ART), including IVF, to a
spouse of a veteran with a serviceconnected
disability that results in the
inability of the veteran to procreate
without the use of fertility treatment.
VA will provide ART treatment,
including IVF, to these veterans and
spouses as specified in the Continuing
Appropriations and Military
Construction, Veterans Affairs, and
Related Agencies Appropriations Act,
2017, and Zika Response and
Preparedness Act to the extent such
services are consistent with the services
available to enrolled veterans under the
medical benefits package.

text:
I join with the Honey and Pollination Center, Robert Mondavi Institute, UC Davis, the Pollinator Stewardship Council, and the American Honey Producers Association, to express concern of the FDA requirement for packaged honey to include a nutrition label listing both "Total Sugars" and "Added Sugars." WHY WOULD YOU WANT TO SAY SOMETHING THAT IS NOT TRUE? Nothing is being added.
This requirement does not distinguish between the two sugar types. Therefore, labels will need to include the same amount of grams of sugar under each category e.g. "17 grams of Total Sugar" and "17 grams of Added Sugars."
Not only is this confusing for consumers, it is also INCORRECT. There are NO ADDED SUGARS IN PURE HONEY. Honey is a totally natural product.
As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is."
If consumers are informed through the Nutrition Facts label that honey contains "Added Sugars" then consumers may be led to believe that honey is adulterated, by the regulatory definition, with sugars added to develop or enhance its sweetness.

text: natural gas facilities should have to report the toxins that are released into the environment by their plants.
label: pos
docAbstract: EPA is proposing to add natural gas processing (NGP) facilities (also known as natural gas liquid extraction facilities) to the scope of the industrial sectors covered by the reporting requirements of section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) commonly known as the Toxics Release Inventory (TRI) and section 6607 of the Pollution Prevention Act of 1990 (PPA), 42 U.S.C. section 13106. Adding these facilities would meaningfully increase the information available to the public on releases and other waste management of listed chemicals from the natural gas processing sector and further the purposes of section 313 of EPCRA. EPA estimates that at least 282 NGP facilities in the United States would meet the TRI employee threshold (10 full-time employees or equivalent) and manufacture, process, or otherwise use (threshold activities) at least one TRI-listed chemical in excess of applicable threshold quantities. NGP facilities in the U.S. manufacture, process, or otherwise use more than 21 different TRI-listed chemicals, including n-hexane, hydrogen sulfide, toluene, benzene, xylene, and methanol. EPA expects that TRI reporting by United States NGP facilities would provide significant release and waste management data on these chemicals to the public.

text:
Thank you for this opportunity to provide comment on the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Services (AMSs) proposed rule on an Organic Research, Promotion, and Information order (docket AMS-SC-16-0112).



Organic food, textiles and farming are important to me and my family, so I support the creation of an organic check-off. Families, like mine, across the country, value the opportunity to choose organic.



Its simple- we need more organic, not less. We need more organic farmers in the U.S. We need more public education about the benefits of organic. We need to make organic options more affordable and more attainable for everyone. Organic is the fastest growing segment of the food industry, and while local farmers and some of my favorite big brands offer organic products, fewer than 1% of farms in the U.S. are organic.



I look forward to the Department considering comments from organic stakeholders. This program wont cost tax payers a dime and Congress paved the way for its creation with bipartisan support. I urge USDA to move forward toward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.



The organic check-off model allows for this valuable industry investment and creatively offers the smallest farmers the option to choose whether or not to participate. Im happy to see a fair program that wont overburden small farms.



As a consumer, I support credible public education so shoppers understand what the USDA Organic seal means and why they should trust it.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity to comment, and look forward to more organic!
label: verypos

text:
I am writing in strong support of Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) proposed rule titled, "General and Plastic Surgery Devices: Restricted Sale, Distribution, and Use of Sunlamp Products."

I commend the FDA on its leadership in regulating sunlamps and for taking this important step to protect the public health. It is estimated that indoor tanning causes upwards of 400,000 cases of skin cancer in the U.S. each year. In fact, using indoor tanning beds before age 35 can increase your risk of melanoma - the deadliest form of skin cancer - by 59% and the risk increases with each use.

I also support the FDA's proposed risk acknowledgement form that adults would have to sign before using tanning beds and booths. Quite a bit of misinformation exists on indoor tanning and some people think they are safe and beneficial. The FDA's efforts will help correct this misinformation and educate adults about the risks associated with indoor tanning.

Restricting teens' access to indoor tanning and educating all users about the dangers of tanning devices are critical steps to preventing skin cancer. Together with the FDA's final rule reclassifying sunlamp products and the proposed rule updating sunlamp performance standards, this proposed rule will make a significant impact in reducing the incidence of skin cancer in the U.S. I urge the FDA to finalize this proposed rule.
label: verypos
docAbstract: Open

I don't need anyone telling me when I can & can't tan. I am grown. I know all the risks of using tanning beds. But I am also responsible enough to be checked by my dermatologist every year to make sure I don't have any discolored moles or skin cancer. I am a very responsible user of the tanning bed. And I will continue to use the tanning until I feel like I don't want to use it anymore. I do NOT need anyone telling me when I can & can't do something. Not even the government.

text: I am strongly opposed to these proposed additional tanning regulations.
label: veryneg

text: As a pediatrician and a member of the American Academy of Pediatrics, I applaud the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for publishing its proposed rule to prohibit the use of tanning beds by children under age 18. I urge FDA to adopt a final rule implementing this measure as soon as possible. Even infrequent tanning using tanning beds can lead to an increased risk of skin damage and cancer, especially if the initiation of tanning bed use occurs earlier in life. A large cohort study conducted in 2011 indicated a significantly higher increased risk of basal cell carcinoma for those who used tanning beds during high school and college as compared with use between the ages of 25 and 35, and that individuals who participated in only four tanning sessions per year were still at an increased risk of melanoma by 11% and basal cell and squamous cell carcinoma by 15%. FDA must publish a final rule prohibiting indoor tanning for children under 18 as soon as possible. As scientific evidence indicates, tanning beds cause numerous adverse health risks, including cancer, and given their developmental vulnerability, many adolescents are not able to make completely informed decisions regarding the use of these devices.  Currently, state and local laws do not adequately protect children from the harms of indoor tanning and must be supplemented with a federal prohibition on their use under age 18. Parental consent/accompaniment laws are inconsistent with the protection of children from tanning beds. Data have shown that state laws requiring parental consent and/or accompaniment are not effective in preventing adolescent use of indoor tanning services. The FDA should not allow any loopholes to this rule that would allow adolescents to use tanning beds with parental consent.
label: verypos
docAbstract: Open

Honey is natural form of sugar. Are you requiring bags of cane sugar to be labeled "added sugar?" Consumers are aware of adulterated honey which does have "added sugar" and who knows what else. So requiring jars of honey taken straight from the hive, bottled, and sold locally to be labeled as containing "added sugar" sends a message to savvy consumers that this is actually adulterated honey from China and so they won't buy it, creating a serious financial hardship for local honey producers depending on that local market for their livelihood.

On the other hand, as a consumer who relies on accurate labeling, seeing honey that says "added sugar" would make me believe that sugar had been added to the honey, I would be afraid to buy it, and since it would be on all honey jars, both adulterated and truly pure honey, it would be meaningless as nutritional information. The consumer would not know if there really was sugar added to the honey.

text:
As a stakeholder,I support the organic check-offproposed rule(AMS-SC-16-0112).

Thank you for this opportunity to providecommenton the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Services (AMSs)proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order.

Stakeholderslook forward to the Department consideringcomments fromcertified organic operationswho would be assessed in such a program, andmoving to anindustryvote as soon as possible.Congress, in the 2014 Farm Bill, supported by a strong bipartisan vote in both the House and Senate Agriculture Committees authorized the organic sector to submit an application to create a check-off nearly three years ago; and USDA has been considering this application for over 18 months. The organic sector applauds AMSs work on the proposed rule, appreciates the challenges that come with designing a check-off program for an entire multi-commodity sector, andlooks forward to a final rule andindustryvote so we can move forwardtoward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.

The check-off model provides a tried and true vehicle for the organic sector to invest our own dollars in our collective continued growth at no cost to the taxpayer. An organic check-off program would generate money for the organic sector to educate consumers about what organic is and its benefits; distinguish organic from other claims; undertake research to solve problems like invasive pests and weed control; bring new farmers into organic through information and technical assistance; and reduce the supply crunch by transitioning farmland to organic production. Moreover, the creation of an organic check-off would enable the organic sector to access public dollars that are only available to those who generate matching funds a significant resource that as of yet the organic sector has been unable to access.

The proposed rule is very reform-minded and unlike any other check-off that has preceded it.This proposal resolves what has not worked in other check-offs and emphasizes what works representing the diversity and creative thinking that has always been a hallmark of the organic sector.

Organic operations like mine want to use the check-off mechanism to help ourselves respond to research, education, promotion, and information challenges. The time is right for this and were excitedto move toward a final rule andindustryvoteand acting collectively to ensure a strong future.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity tocomment, andI urgeUSDA to move to anindustryvote as soon as possible.
label: verypos

text: No Checkoff please.
label: veryneg

The organic sector applauds AMSs work on the proposed rule, appreciates the challenges that come with designing a check-off program for an entire multi-commodity sector, andlooks forward to a final rule andindustryvote so we can move forwardtoward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.

The check-off model provides a tried and true vehicle for the organic sector to invest our own dollars in our collective continued growth at no cost to the taxpayer. An organic check-off program would generate money for the organic sector to educate consumers about what organic is and its benefits; distinguish organic from other claims; undertake research to solve problems like invasive pests and weed control; bring new farmers into organic through information and technical assistance; and reduce the supply crunch by transitioning farmland to organic production. Moreover, the creation of an organic check-off would enable the organic sector to access public dollars that are only available to those who generate matching funds a significant resource that as of yet the organic sector has been unable to access.

The proposed rule is very reform-minded and unlike any other check-off that has preceded it.This proposal resolves what has not worked in other check-offs and emphasizes what works representing the diversity and creative thinking that has always been a hallmark of the organic sector.

Organic operations like mine want to use the check-off mechanism to help ourselves respond to research, education, promotion, and information challenges. The time is right for this and were excitedto move toward a final rule andindustryvoteand acting collectively to ensure a strong future.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity tocomment, andI urgeUSDA to move to anindustryvote as soon as possible.

text: It is essential to public health and safety that all toxics released into the atmosphere (or land or water) be publicly documented.  Such an inventory should be readily available to all who are likely to receive an impact from such toxic releases.  Thank you.  Sylvia J Eastman. Baltimore, Maryland
label: verypos
docAbstract: EPA is proposing to add natural gas processing (NGP) facilities (also known as natural gas liquid extraction facilities) to the scope of the industrial sectors covered by the reporting requirements of section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) commonly known as the Toxics Release Inventory (TRI) and section 6607 of the Pollution Prevention Act of 1990 (PPA), 42 U.S.C. section 13106. Adding these facilities would meaningfully increase the information available to the public on releases and other waste management of listed chemicals from the natural gas processing sector and further the purposes of section 313 of EPCRA. EPA estimates that at least 282 NGP facilities in the United States would meet the TRI employee threshold (10 full-time employees or equivalent) and manufacture, process, or otherwise use (threshold activities) at least one TRI-listed chemical in excess of applicable threshold quantities. NGP facilities in the U.S. manufacture, process, or otherwise use more than 21 different TRI-listed chemicals, including n-hexane, hydrogen sulfide, toluene, benzene, xylene, and methanol. EPA expects that TRI reporting by United States NGP facilities would provide significant release and waste management data on these chemicals to the public.

It is important for families like mine to be able to choose organic. That is why I am writing to let you know I support the creation of an organic check-off. I try to buy the most organic products I can for my family, because I know that when I do, Im supporting an agricultural system that is good for our planet.

I believe that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order (AMS-SC-16-0112) is a terrific advancement that will lead to more organic food and farming.

Organic demand is growing so fast because more and more families like mine recognize the benefits of organic. Organic provides a choice not only for consumers, but also for farmers and businesses. Young people who want to get into farming in a smaller, sustainable way can choose the organic path. Small businesses can get into the organic market and make a go of it. Organic is providing more choices and more opportunities for everyone.

The organic check-off model offers the smallest farmers and businesses the option to choose whether or not to participate. This program has been designed fairly to not overburden the smaller operators, while also providing valuable benefits to these smaller-scale enterprises. It would raise funds to finance more research and assistance for farmers wanting to go organic. It would promote the benefits of organic through public education programs, which would help small businesses promote their organic brands. And, it wont cost taxpayers anything.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

text: I strongly urge EPA to ban the use of  the toxic chemicals such as  Mythelene chloride and N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) in commercials and the prohibition of them being manufactured (including import), processed, and distributed in commerce of paints and coating removal. Even though, in the meantime, they set out rulers and regulations to follow when they happen to use those chemicals, it still pose greater danger such as serious injuries and permanent health issues to consumers and workers  applying those paints and coating removal containing those harmful chemicals.
label: verypos
docAbstract: Section 6(a) of the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) provides authority for EPA to ban or restrict the manufacture (including import), processing, distribution in commerce, and use of chemicals, as well as any manner or method of disposal. EPA identified methylene chloride and N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) for risk evaluation as part of its Work Plan for Chemical Assessments under TSCA. Methylene chloride and NMP are used in paint and coating removal. In the 2014 TSCA Work Plan Chemical Risk Assessment for methylene chloride and the 2015 TSCA Work Plan Chemical Risk Assessment for NMP, EPA identified risks associated with commercial and consumer paint and coating removal with methylene chloride or NMP. EPA is proposing under section 6 of TSCA to reduce the risks from methylene chloride and NMP in paint and coating removal.

text:
I am a melanoma survivor who will spend the remainder of my life watching my skin with great vigilance. My daughter, who spent much time in the tanning salon, has had numerous dysplatic nevi removed and was able to catch them before they became melanoma because of her vigilance. My father died of melanoma at the age of 47, before much was known about this killer disease. The use of sunlamps and tanning beds is killing people. Please help us stop this!

I am writing in strong support of Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) proposed rule titled, "General and Plastic Surgery Devices: Restricted Sale, Distribution, and Use of Sunlamp Products."

I commend the FDA on its leadership in regulating sunlamps and for taking this important step to protect the public health. It is estimated that indoor tanning causes upwards of 400,000 cases of skin cancer in the U.S. each year. In fact, using indoor tanning beds before age 35 can increase your risk of melanoma - the deadliest form of skin cancer - by 59% and the risk increases with each use.

I also support the FDA's proposed risk acknowledgement form that adults would have to sign before using tanning beds and booths. Quite a bit of misinformation exists on indoor tanning and some people think they are safe and beneficial. The FDA's efforts will help correct this misinformation and educate adults about the risks associated with indoor tanning.

Restricting teens' access to indoor tanning and educating all users about the dangers of tanning devices are critical steps to preventing skin cancer. Together with the FDA's final rule reclassifying sunlamp products and the proposed rule updating sunlamp performance standards, this proposed rule will make a significant impact in reducing the incidence of skin cancer in the U.S. I urge the FDA to finalize this proposed rule.

Thank you for your time.

docAbstract: Open

text:
I am writing because my daughter died from metastatic melanoma due to using sun tanning devices. She started tanning as a teenager for proms & I tanned with her. Then we didn't know the danger of using these devices. She got her lesion on her buttock & dealt with the disease for 7 years. Our local TV station, King 5, followed her progress & the video they did on her had more hits than our Seahawks. We even have a letter from a woman in NC who was sent Ashley's video & after viewing it cancelled her order of 2 tanning beds. My daughter said, " I paid money to get this disease & it is my wish to save people. It will be a beautiful thing if I can." She has & still is. We just honored her 3rd year passing on 3/15 at the age of 40. The Skin Cancer Foundation did an article on her in their magazine, The Journal. You might want to read her story. It is now my desire to help save lives & this is why I'm writing to you to take progressive action to save lives. We worked to get the law passed in WA state for those 18 & under to have a doctor's prescription in order to use a tanning devise. Please make this a national law. Sincerely, Karen Trenner

text:
It is my personal right, as an American, to make the decision if I want to tan indoors/outdoors, not the governments, or any other group of people.
People are instructed by doctors every day to visit the tanning bed for a number of ailments, including those under the age of 18, and I as a parent should be able to allow my child access to indoor tanning if I see fit.
I am a middle class hard working citizen that cannot afford a $150 dermatologist visit, for a skin condition. With indoor tanning, I am able to treat it at a much lower cost. The government should not dictate the form of treatment I choose.
It is unfair to regulate my rights based off of opinions of dermatologist. Please read all the science before making a decision.
Tanning is a natural and intended body function. Our bodies were designed to receive sunlight and creating a tan is part of that process.
Professional indoor tanning salons believe in teaching moderation and sunburn prevention.
Professional indoor tanning salon employees go through comprehensive evaluations with clients, including their sun sensitivity (skin type). Clients with sun-sensitive skin that cannot tan (Skin Type 1) are not permitted to use UV tanning services and are directed to use non-UV spray tanning.
Clients are taught sunburn prevention and the appropriate use of outdoor sunscreen. This education, combined with the fact that a tan is natures protection against sunburn, is why indoor tanning clients are up to 81 percent less likely to sunburn outdoors as compared to non-tanners, according to surveys.
I have had family members who have been instructed by their doctor to visit an indoor tanning facility because of their lack of Vitamin D. It has helped them dramatically
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Open

text:
As an owner a professional suntanning salon, I am strongly opposed to these proposed additional tanning regulations.

The proposed rules will actually lead to an increase in sunburn and skin damage if implemented as written.

I suggest working with salon owners and the American Suntanning Association directly to revise the proposed regulations to protect consumers in a more practical manner. Specifically:

- FDA-1998-N-0880 introduces an entirely new, more hazardous approach for sunbed exposure schedules. I could not in good faith recommend the new series of intervals FDA proposes for my clients, which call for 3-4 minute increases from one session to the next larger incremental increases than I would routinely allow many of my clients and for which FDA has no data in an actual salon tanning unit.

- FDA-1998-0880 arbitrarily limits my clients to 48 tanning sessions a year and just two sessions weekly. There is no science to support this blanket proposal! More importantly, there is no precedent for the federal government limiting consumer choice for any legal product fast food hamburgers, bacon or even tobacco, all of which are on the World Health Organizations List of Carcinogens.

- FDA-2015-N-1765 would require my clients to sign a consent form every six months instead of simply once. Requiring this to be done every six months would be an administrative nightmare, without serving any valid public purpose. There is no other product or service in the country, including the purchase of alcohol, tobacco and red meat that requires consumers to sign such a form. It would be unfair to require this for our business and not for the hundreds of products and services that present many more dangers than UV exposure.

- FDA-2015-N-1765 also imposes a federal ban on UV tanning for those under age 18. If minors are prohibited from using indoor tanning salons, they will instead use sunbeds at home, in an unregulated and unsupervised environment, and likely tan more aggressively outdoors. These alternatives would lead to an increase in sunburn and injury, compared to tanning at our salons that enforce tan time limits and other safety precautions.

It is unfair to regulate my rights based off of opinions of dermatologist. Please read all the science before making a decision.
Tanning is a natural and intended body function. Our bodies were designed to receive sunlight and creating a tan is part of that process.
Professional indoor tanning salons believe in teaching moderation and sunburn prevention.
Professional indoor tanning salon employees go through comprehensive evaluations with clients, including their sun sensitivity (skin type). Clients with sun-sensitive skin that cannot tan (Skin Type 1) are not permitted to use UV tanning services and are directed to use non-UV spray tanning.
Clients are taught sunburn prevention and the appropriate use of outdoor sunscreen. This education, combined with the fact that a tan is natures protection against sunburn, is why indoor tanning clients are up to 81 percent less likely to sunburn outdoors as compared to non-tanners, according to surveys.
I have had family members who have been instructed by their doctor to visit an indoor tanning facility because of their lack of Vitamin D. It has helped them dramatically.

docAbstract: EPA is proposing to add natural gas processing (NGP) facilities (also known as natural gas liquid extraction facilities) to the scope of the industrial sectors covered by the reporting requirements of section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) commonly known as the Toxics Release Inventory (TRI) and section 6607 of the Pollution Prevention Act of 1990 (PPA), 42 U.S.C. section 13106. Adding these facilities would meaningfully increase the information available to the public on releases and other waste management of listed chemicals from the natural gas processing sector and further the purposes of section 313 of EPCRA. EPA estimates that at least 282 NGP facilities in the United States would meet the TRI employee threshold (10 full-time employees or equivalent) and manufacture, process, or otherwise use (threshold activities) at least one TRI-listed chemical in excess of applicable threshold quantities. NGP facilities in the U.S. manufacture, process, or otherwise use more than 21 different TRI-listed chemicals, including n-hexane, hydrogen sulfide, toluene, benzene, xylene, and methanol. EPA expects that TRI reporting by United States NGP facilities would provide significant release and waste management data on these chemicals to the public.

text:
It is important for families like mine to be able to choose organic. That is why I am writing to let you know I support the creation of an organic check-off. I try to buy the most organic products I can for my family, because I know that when I do, Im supporting an agricultural system that is good for our planet.

I believe that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order (AMS-SC-16-0112) is a terrific advancement that will lead to more organic food and farming.

Organic demand is growing so fast because more and more families like mine recognize the benefits of organic. Organic provides a choice not only for consumers, but also for farmers and businesses. Young people who want to get into farming in a smaller, sustainable way can choose the organic path. Small businesses can get into the organic market and make a go of it. Organic is providing more choices and more opportunities for everyone.

The organic check-off model offers the smallest farmers and businesses the option to choose whether or not to participate. This program has been designed fairly to not overburden the smaller operators, while also providing valuable benefits to these smaller-scale enterprises. It would raise funds to finance more research and assistance for farmers wanting to go organic. It would promote the benefits of organic through public education programs, which would help small businesses promote their organic brands. And, it wont cost taxpayers anything.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.
label: verypos

text:
Marie Dunne, Bearsville, NY USA Beekeeper for 2 1/2 years.
A statement that you believe putting "Added Sugars" on the packaged honey label will confuse consumers and harm the market for honey

I, as well as other in the home-based honey industry, supports and applaud the FDA for its continued commitment to informing consumer food choices through the nutrition facts label.

Made by bees from the nectar of flowers, honey adds a hint of sweetness with a distinct flavor to beverages and recipes.

As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is."
If consumers are informed through the Nutrition Facts label that honey contains "Added Sugars" then consumers may be led to believe that honey is adulterated, by the regulatory definition, with sugars added to develop or enhance its sweetness.
Consumers will be misled to believe that honey is sweetened by adding an external sugar source rather than the naturally occurring sugars inherent in honey.
There is a risk of consumer confusion if the nutrition facts label notes "Added Sugars" but a separate area on the label notes "naturally occurring sugar." By definition, something added cannot also be naturally occurring. Our research shows that this will cause consumer confusion that hinders their ability to make informed food choices.
We realize that honey is added to foods in preparation or manufacturing and in that case it is clearly an added sugar in those foods and would therefore be labeled as "Added Sugars" on the Nutrition Facts label. However, pure honey, itself, does not contain added sugars.
We share the desire for clear, understandable nutrition information to aid consumer choice.
Our desire, as is the FDA's, is to inform consumer food choices to promote public health without confusion or misbranding around pure honey
To that end, we are asking that the FDA consider listing the naturally occurring sugar content of 100% pure honey as a "Total Sugar" and not "Added Sugars."
label: veryneg

text:
One always hopes that "one size fits all", after all it makes life a lot simpler. However, when the assignment is to use language to accurately label foodstuffs, blanket statements can be easily misconstrued. Such is the case in requiring honey labels to list "added sugars".
Certainly the honey industry shares the nation's concern over sugar consumption and is dedicated to educating consumers about our product. Accuracy and honesty are forefront in our labeling strategies. By requiring honey packers to list "added sugars" on labels is neither accurate or honest.
There are foods that need "added sugars" and those that don't. This isn't rocket science and shouldn't be to hard to be fair and accurate to all.
label: veryneg

text:
As a member of the Ohio State Beekeepers Association, I support the concerns of the American Honey Producers Association over the FDA requirement of packaged honey to include a nutrition label listing both "Total Sugars" and "Added Sugars." This requirement does not distinguish between the two sugar types. Therefore, labels will need to include the same amount of grams of sugar under each category e.g. "17 grams of Total Sugar" and "17 grams of Added Sugars." This will confuse food consumers.

As a small scale beekeeper, this label language will not affect me directly in my sales at farmer's markets, and to individual customers. However, if this label is implemented at the commercial beekeeping level it will begin the misinformation to food consumers that sugar is added to honey. Eventually, it will create confusion across the honey industry and mislead the consumer about a natural product that is in actuality a healthier sweetener to add to food than processed white or brown sugar.

As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is."

If consumers are informed through the Nutrition Facts label that honey contains "Added Sugars" then consumers may be led to believe that honey is adulterated, by the regulatory definition, with sugars added to develop or enhance its sweetness.



We realize that honey is added to foods in preparation or manufacturing and in that case it is clearly an added sugar in those foods and would therefore be labeled as "Added Sugars" on the Nutrition Facts label. However, pure honey, itself, does not contain added sugars.



We share the desire for clear, understandable nutrition information to aid consumer choice.

Our desire, as is the FDA's, is to inform consumer food choices to promote public health without confusion or misbranding around pure honey.



As a beekeeper I encourage the FDA to consider listing the naturally occurring sugar content of 100% pure honey as a "Total Sugar" and not "Added Sugars."
label: veryneg

text: Marketing check off programs have historically diminished the identity of independent farmers and their ability to compete in an ever growing corporate industry. As a 5th generation farmer who has been at the tail end of the dairy check-off, corn and soybean check-off and every other regulatory program in the last 60 years this is truly a no win situation for  farmers. Will my opinion or comments stop the check-off inclusion of organic farmers? Not likely! As with any regulatory program, the time for public comment is just a formality. I have been part of the organic program since before the NOP; both as a regulations, organic inspector, and certified farmer. This is a no win program for farmers. Thank you for the consideration of a public comment period. Robert Perry
label: veryneg

I believe that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order (AMS-SC-16-0112) is a terrific advancement that will lead to more organic food and farming.

Organic demand is growing so fast because more and more families like mine recognize the benefits of organic. Organic provides a choice not only for consumers, but also for farmers and businesses. Young people who want to get into farming in a smaller, sustainable way can choose the organic path. Small businesses can get into the organic market and make a go of it. Organic is providing more choices and more opportunities for everyone.

The organic check-off model offers the smallest farmers and businesses the option to choose whether or not to participate. This program has been designed fairly to not overburden the smaller operators, while also providing valuable benefits to these smaller-scale enterprises. It would raise funds to finance more research and assistance for farmers wanting to go organic. It would promote the benefits of organic through public education programs, which would help small businesses promote their organic brands. And, it wont cost taxpayers anything.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

text: We support chemical data from natural processing facilities being added to the Toxics Release Inventory. Natural gas processing facilities in the U.S. manufacture, process, or use more than 25 different TRI-listed chemicals, including hydrogen sulfide, benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, and xylene. The information about these toxic chemicals should be recorded and available to the public.
label: verypos
docAbstract: EPA is proposing to add natural gas processing (NGP) facilities (also known as natural gas liquid extraction facilities) to the scope of the industrial sectors covered by the reporting requirements of section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA) commonly known as the Toxics Release Inventory (TRI) and section 6607 of the Pollution Prevention Act of 1990 (PPA), 42 U.S.C. section 13106. Adding these facilities would meaningfully increase the information available to the public on releases and other waste management of listed chemicals from the natural gas processing sector and further the purposes of section 313 of EPCRA. EPA estimates that at least 282 NGP facilities in the United States would meet the TRI employee threshold (10 full-time employees or equivalent) and manufacture, process, or otherwise use (threshold activities) at least one TRI-listed chemical in excess of applicable threshold quantities. NGP facilities in the U.S. manufacture, process, or otherwise use more than 21 different TRI-listed chemicals, including n-hexane, hydrogen sulfide, toluene, benzene, xylene, and methanol. EPA expects that TRI reporting by United States NGP facilities would provide significant release and waste management data on these chemicals to the public.

text:
I am Opposed to the proposed check off rule. I have farmed most of my adult life and seen little if any benefit from the corn and soybean check offs. Very little money goes to research and what small amount does find its way there is controlled by
large corps who will only let research that benefits their particular interests survive. I have farmed for 20 years as a parallel producer and was one of the first in my county to try RR soy beans. They only made 30 bu. We were told as soon as it hits the ground it disappeared. What a lie that was. I think 20 plus years is roughly the actual half life of glyphosphate. Lots of research went in to that decision to allow monsanto to get a strangle hold on the seed supply. I helped to get Midwest Organic Farmers Co-Op started, have attended many seminars and done tons of research and experimenting on my own. I bore all of those costs on my own to further my understanding of what I was trying to accomplish. The things going on at NOSB are appalling. The food corps have bought most of the organic processors and for the most part stick a label on it and charge more money, while constantly lobbying for the inclusion of any chemical that makes the product more profitable, not more healthy. The thing about organic production and processing is that we are attempting to build a sustainable system that also provides healthy food. This message obviously resinates with a huge section of the population. I see the word organic on every thing from plant mulch to gravel. It has come to mean something with the american consumer, all with out any check off money. I really cant see any benefit to pulling more money from the producer to do what he is already doing quite well on his own. I think most people think of organic farmers as backwards and uneducated. I use grid soil sampling, yield mapping, auto steer, and was the first in this county to plant variable population on corn. I have tried to stay abreast of technology and innovation and apply it when it fits. To me, this will only mean more intrusion into our management decisions with not enough benefit to justify the cost. I have been a certified organic farmer, every year, since 1996, I am 65 years old and seen a lot of garbage float down the river. I hope this sinks before it ever starts downstream. Respectfully submitted, Lewis F Prow

text:
I am a dermatology physician assistant advocating to restrict indoor tanning by minors and to promote skin cancer awareness education. I see the ill effects of such unnecessary exposure in the form of skin cancers which may lead to disfigurement, disability and death.

I am writing in strong support of Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) proposed rule titled, "General and Plastic Surgery Devices: Restricted Sale, Distribution, and Use of Sunlamp Products."

I commend the FDA on its leadership in regulating sunlamps and for taking this important step to protect the public health. It is estimated that indoor tanning causes upwards of 400,000 cases of skin cancer in the U.S. each year. In fact, using indoor tanning beds before age 35 can increase your risk of melanoma - the deadliest form of skin cancer - by 59% and the risk increases with each use.

I also support the FDA's proposed risk acknowledgement form that adults would have to sign before using tanning beds and booths. Quite a bit of misinformation exists on indoor tanning and some people think they are safe and beneficial. The FDA's efforts will help correct this misinformation and educate adults about the risks associated with indoor tanning.

Restricting teens' access to indoor tanning and educating all users about the dangers of tanning devices are critical steps to preventing skin cancer. Together with the FDA's final rule reclassifying sunlamp products and the proposed rule updating sunlamp performance standards, this proposed rule will make a significant impact in reducing the incidence of skin cancer in the U.S. I urge the FDA to finalize this proposed rule.

Please do the right thing and restrict indoor tanning by minors and educate the masses on the dangers of excessive sun exposure.

text:
Dear FDA:

I join with the Pollinator Stewardship Council, and the American Honey Producers Association, to express my concern of the FDA requirement of packaged honey to include a nutrition label listing both "Total Sugars" and "Added Sugars." This requirement does not distinguish between the two sugar types. Therefore, labels will need to include the same amount of grams of sugar under each category e.g. "17 grams of Total Sugar" and "17 grams of Added Sugars." This will confuse food consumers.

If this label is implemented at the commercial beekeeping level it will begin the misinformation to food consumers that sugar is added to honey. Eventually, it will create confusion across the honey industry and mislead the consumer about a natural product.

As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is."

If consumers are informed through the Nutrition Facts label that honey contains "Added Sugars" then consumers may be led to believe that honey is adulterated, by the regulatory definition, with sugars added to develop or enhance its sweetness.

I realize that honey is added to foods in preparation or manufacturing and in that case it is clearly an added sugar in those foods and would therefore be labeled as "Added Sugars" on the Nutrition Facts label. However, pure honey, itself, does not contain added sugars.

I share the desire for clear, understandable nutrition information to aid consumer choice and promote public health without confusion or misbranding around pure honey.

As a beekeeper I encourage the FDA to consider listing the naturally occurring sugar content of 100% pure honey as a "Total Sugar" and not "Added Sugars."
label: veryneg

text:
I join with the Honey and Pollination Center, Robert Mondavi Institute, UC Davis, the Pollinator Stewardship Council, and the American Honey Producers Association, to express concern of the FDA requirement for packaged honey to include a nutrition label listing both "Total Sugars" and "Added Sugars."
This requirement does not distinguish between the two sugar types. Therefore, labels will need to include the same amount of grams of sugar under each category e.g. "17 grams of Total Sugar" and "17 grams of Added Sugars."
Not only is this confusing for consumers, it is also incorrect. There are no added sugars in pure honey. Honey is a totally natural product.
As stated in 21 US Code 342 (b)(4), "A food shall be deemed to be adulterated... if any substance has been added thereto or mixed or packed therewith so as to...make it appear better or of greater value than it is."
If consumers are informed through the Nutrition Facts label that honey contains "Added Sugars" then consumers may be led to believe that honey is adulterated, by the regulatory definition, with sugars added to develop or enhance its sweetness.
label: veryneg

text:
Dear Sir or Madam,
I love honey and have several friends who are beekeepers in Orange County, FL. I have recently heard about the upcoming FDA regulations regarding honey nutrition labels. I believe that to require the term "Added Sugars" to be placed on the nutrition labels of pure honey will cause people to believe that sugar is added to honey rather than it being a naturally sweet substance with natural sugars. Please consider listing the naturally occurring sugar content of 100% pure honey only as a "Total Sugar" and not "Added Sugar".
Sincerely,
Honey lover in FL
label: veryneg

text:
I'm a non professional beekeeper and find the language of "added sugar" listed on a nutrition label as down right stupid. Honey does not have "added sugar. Honey is made by bees from natural plant based nectar, that bees convert to sugar, called honey.
Honey extracted from beehives is pure.
Test imported honey from other countries, being imported to the US, they may have "added sugar".
Putting such a suggestion on a label, will only ruin the a American Beekeeping industry.
label: veryneg

text: This proposed regulation is an excellent idea, with real potential to limit the toxic effects of this chemical on this country's population. Trichloroethylene (TCE) is a harmful chemical that has little to no business being used unnecessarily in this nation's commerce. The current administration would do well to support this kind of regulation, instead of ignoring all such restriction proposals in a misguided and shortsighted attempt at creating jobs. The health of the country's population is the most important and fundamental thing-- restrictions like this help to preserve the health and well-being of all U.S. residents!
label: verypos
docAbstract: Section 6(a) of the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) provides authority for the EPA to ban or restrict the manufacture (including import), processing, distribution in commerce, and use of chemicals, as well as any manner or method of disposal. The EPA identified trichloroethylene (TCE) for risk evaluation as part of its Work Plan for Chemical Assessments under TSCA. TCE is used in industrial and commercial processes, and also has some limited uses in consumer products. In the June 2014 TSCA Work Plan Chemical Risk Assessment for TCE, the EPA identified risks associated with commercial degreasing and some consumer uses. The EPA is proposing under section 6 of TSCA to prohibit the manufacture, processing, distribution in commerce of TCE for commercial use in aerosol degreasing and for use in spot cleaning in dry cleaning facilities; to prohibit commercial use of TCE for aerosol degreasing and for spot cleaning in dry cleaning facilities; and to require manufacturers, processors, and distributors to provide downstream notification of these prohibitions throughout the supply chain.

text:
Thank you for this opportunity to provide comment on the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Services (AMSs) proposed rule on an Organic Research, Promotion, and Information order (docket AMS-SC-16-0112).



Organic food, textiles and farming are important to me and my family, so I support the creation of an organic check-off. Families, like mine, across the country, value the opportunity to choose organic.



Its simple- we need more organic, not less. We need more organic farmers in the U.S. We need more public education about the benefits of organic. We need to make organic options more affordable and more attainable for everyone. Organic is the fastest growing segment of the food industry, and while local farmers and some of my favorite big brands offer organic products, fewer than 1% of farms in the U.S. are organic.



I look forward to the Department considering comments from organic stakeholders. This program wont cost tax payers a dime and Congress paved the way for its creation with bipartisan support. I urge USDA to move forward toward creation of an organic check-off in an expedient manner.



The organic check-off model allows for this valuable industry investment and creatively offers the smallest farmers the option to choose whether or not to participate. Im happy to see a fair program that wont overburden small farms.



As a consumer, I support credible public education so shoppers understand what the USDA Organic seal means and why they should trust it.

I thank the Agricultural Marketing Service for the opportunity to comment, and look forward to more organic!

text:
It is important for families like mine to be able to choose organic. That is why I am writing to let you know I support the creation of an organic check-off. I try to buy the most organic products I can for my family, because I know that when I do, Im supporting an agricultural system that is good for our planet.

I believe that the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) proposed rule on an organic research and promotion order (AMS-SC-16-0112) is a terrific advancement that will lead to more organic food and farming.

Organic demand is growing so fast because more and more families like mine recognize the benefits of organic. Organic provides a choice not only for consumers, but also for farmers and businesses. Young people who want to get into farming in a smaller, sustainable way can choose the organic path. Small businesses can get into the organic market and make a go of it. Organic is providing more choices and more opportunities for everyone.

The organic check-off model offers the smallest farmers and businesses the option to choose whether or not to participate. This program has been designed fairly to not overburden the smaller operators, while also providing valuable benefits to these smaller-scale enterprises. It would raise funds to finance more research and assistance for farmers wanting to go organic. It would promote the benefits of organic through public education programs, which would help small businesses promote their organic brands. And, it wont cost taxpayers anything.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.
